articles.headline: Sunni Ministers Threaten to Quit Cabinet in Iraq
articles.snippet: Members of Parliament’s largest Sunni bloc are frustrated over the government’s failure to act on Sunni concerns.
articles.abstract: Members of Parliament’s largest Sunni bloc are frustrated over the government’s failure to act on Sunni concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 30 — The largest bloc of Sunni Arabs in the Iraqi Parliament threatened to withdraw its ministers from the Shiite-dominated cabinet on Monday in frustration over the government’s failure to deal with Sunni concerns.

articles.headline: Olmert Rebuked by Israeli Panel on Lebanon War
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Ehud Olmert suffered a further blow today when a Labor minister resigned over the report.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Ehud Olmert suffered a further blow today when a Labor minister resigned over the report.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, May 1 — Despite a resounding chorus of calls in Israel for the prime minister, Ehud Olmert, to resign following a report on Monday that excoriated Mr. Olmert for “severe failures” in last summer’s war against the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, his aides insisted today that he had no intention of leaving office.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: High Court Puts Limits on Patents
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court made it more difficult to get a patent on new products that combine elements of existing inventions.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court made it more difficult to get a patent on new products that combine elements of existing inventions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 30 — The Supreme Court, in its most important patent ruling in years, on Monday raised the bar for obtaining patents on new products that combine elements of pre-existing inventions.

articles.headline: Ex-Senator Seen as Rehearsing for Prime Time
articles.snippet: Fred D. Thompson, the actor and politician, is of the Republican presidential campaign but not in it. Yet.
articles.abstract: Fred D. Thompson, the actor and politician, is of the Republican presidential campaign but not in it. Yet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 30 — When 10 of the declared Republican presidential candidates gather for their first debate on Thursday at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Southern California, Fred D. Thompson, the actor and politician, will not be among them. But he will not be far offstage.

articles.headline: Food Imports Often Escape Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Critics warn that the F.D.A. is woefully understaffed and underfinanced to keep America’s food supply safe.
articles.abstract: Critics warn that the F.D.A. is woefully understaffed and underfinanced to keep America’s food supply safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in the 20th century, the safeguarding of food at American ports often amounted to inspectors from the Food and Drug Administration prying open containers of molasses or sugar and examining them for mold or insect parts.

articles.headline: Recruiting Plankton to Fight Global Warming
articles.snippet: Several groups are working on massive fields of plankton intended to absorb carbon dioxide.
articles.abstract: Several groups are working on massive fields of plankton intended to absorb carbon dioxide.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 — Can plankton help save the planet?

articles.headline: 5 Britons Guilty; Tied to 2005 London Bombers
articles.snippet: Evidence revealed during a trial showed links between the five men and two of the attackers who blew themselves up on London’s transit system.
articles.abstract: Evidence revealed during a trial showed links between the five men and two of the attackers who blew themselves up on London’s transit system.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 30 — A jury found five British Muslim men guilty on Monday of planning fertilizer-bomb attacks around London, ending a yearlong trial that linked the plotters with two of the four men who blew themselves up on London’s transit system in July 2005.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Elaine Sciolino

articles.headline: Two Giants Vie for Bank in Chicago
articles.snippet: LaSalle is at the center of what could be the biggest bank deal ever, as a trophy for Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland.
articles.abstract: LaSalle is at the center of what could be the biggest bank deal ever, as a trophy for Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like deep-dish pizza, the Cubs and a mayor named Daley, LaSalle Bank has long been a Chicago institution. But until a few weeks ago, few would have called it a global banking prize.

articles.headline: As Deportation Pace Rises, Illegal Immigrants Dig In
articles.snippet: Immigrant families are hunkering down and plotting ways to avoid detection and resist deportation, advocates say.
articles.abstract: Immigrant families are hunkering down and plotting ways to avoid detection and resist deportation, advocates say.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW BEDFORD, Mass. — The day after his wife was deported to their home country, Honduras, Lilo Mancía grieved as though she had died.

articles.headline: Accounting Said to Hide Lender Losses
articles.snippet: An accounting technique called gain on sale is haunting New Century Financial as it faces bankruptcy and federal investigations.
articles.abstract: An accounting technique called gain on sale is haunting New Century Financial as it faces bankruptcy and federal investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1998, the chief financial officer of New Century Financial, a lender to home buyers with blemished credit, wrote an unusual paper describing a then little-known accounting technique.
